conclusion: To determine the speed of the elevator at t = 60 seconds, we need to analyze the acceleration-time graph provided and integrate the acceleration over time to find the velocity.
The graph shows acceleration (a) versus time (t).
The elevator starts from rest, so initial velocity (v0) at t = 0 is 0 m/s.
Interval 1: t = 0 to t = 1, acceleration a = 2 m/s².
Interval 2: t = 1 to t = 4, acceleration a = 1 m/s².
Interval 3: t = 4 to t = 5, acceleration a = -1 m/s².
Interval 4: t = 5 to t = 55, acceleration a = 0 m/s².
Interval 5: t = 55 to t = 56, acceleration a = -2 m/s².
Interval 6: t = 56 to t = 59, acceleration a = -1 m/s².
Interval 7: t = 59 to t = 60, acceleration a = 2 m/s².
Interval 1: v = v0 + ∫(0 to 1) 2 dt = 0 + 2 × 1 = 2 m/s.
Interval 4: v = 4 + ∫(5 to 55) 0 dt = 4 m/s (velocity remains constant).
At t = 60 seconds, the speed of the elevator is 1 m/s.
